note: Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã): a horizontal stroke, indicating the number ‚Äúone‚Äù.
Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã) - two parallel lines. Compare with ‰∏Ä, one line meaning one, ‰∏â, three lines meaning three, and ‰∫ñ, four lines meaning four. Duplication of ‰∏Ä (‚Äúone‚Äù).
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì side view of a standing man, highlighting the arms and legs. Compare Â§ß.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a standing person. A radical form of ‰∫∫. Also simplified from ÂÖí (elimination of Ëáº).
Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã) - an arrowhead indicating "to enter". Compare ‰∫∫ (r√©n).

Ideogrammic compound¬†(ÊúÉÊÑè): ÂÖ´ is two bent lines indicating the original meaning of "to divide". This character is later borrowed to mean "eight" because of homonymy, making the original meaning obsolete (now represented by Âà•).

Unlike ‰∏Ä, which was one horizontal stroke meaning one, ÂçÅ was originally simply a vertical stroke. In later forms ‰∏Ä was added, forming a cross.

Perhaps a pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) of a crack in an oracle bone, used for divination in ancient China.  Officially adopted as the simplified form of Ëîî in the Chinese Character Simplification Scheme („ÄäÊº¢Â≠óÁ∞°ÂåñÊñπÊ°à„Äã) in 1956.

Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã) ‚Äì revolving around oneself ‚Äì original character for ÁßÅ (‚Äúselfish; private‚Äù). According to Han Feizi, which was referenced in Shuowen: Compare ÂÖ¨ (‚Äúpublic‚Äù).
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a right hand. Original form of Âè≥ (OC *…¢ ∑…Ø î, *…¢ ∑…Øs, ‚Äúright‚Äù).

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì resembles an open mouth. In the oracle bone script, radical Âè£ is used for characters having abstract meanings. Such a character can have a figurative meaning derived from the phonetic part, e.g. Âè≥ (OC *…¢ ∑…Ø î, *…¢ ∑…Øs, ‚Äúright‚Äù) = Âèà (OC *…¢ ∑…Øs, ‚Äúright hand‚Äù) + Âè£ and ™™∫ (‚Äústrong; powerful‚Äù) = Âºì (OC *k ∑…Ø≈ã, ‚Äúbow‚Äù) + Âè£, or be an unrelated borrowing, e.g. Âê¶ (OC *br…Ø î, *p…Ø î, ‚Äúno‚Äù) = ‰∏ç (OC *p…Ø, *p…Ø î, *p…Ø', ‚Äúcalyx‚Äù) + Âè£.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢): a lump of clay on a potter‚Äôs wheel.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì axe-like tool; soldier.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì footprint (pointing down), variant of Â§Ç. Compare Ê≠¢, which has similar form in oracle script, but has leg pointing up, and °ïí (as in right side of Ëàõ, roughly „É∞), which also has leg pointing down, but toe pointing left, hence different evolutions.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äî moon crescent. Compare Êúà.

Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã): a person ‰∫∫ with arms stretched out as far as possible, implying the meaning of big/great/large. Compare with Â∞¢, which is a man with bent legs. Compare also Êñá, which is a man with arms outstretched and a crest or tattoo on his chest, and to Â§≠, which is a man with arms outstretched and leaning to side (running).

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢): a woman with breasts kneeling or standing. In modern form turned on left side: enclosed area is remnant of left breast (character's left, depicted woman's right), while right breast has disappeared. Graphically cognate to ÊØç (m«î, ‚Äúmother‚Äù), which has developed similarly, but also includes dots for nipples and has retained both breasts.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì an image of a baby, with a large head and spread arms. The legs are wrapped in a blanket. Compare with ‰∫Ü, where the arms are wrapped. The big seal script form is much more elaborate, showing a baby with hair on a head (Âõü) and arms on the two sides of the body, sitting on a stool (Âá†).

Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã) ‚Äì a position on the forearm where the pulse can be palpated by compressing the radial artery. It is called ÂØ∏Âè£ in modern Chinese, and the meaning of a unit of measurement is derived from the distance between the wrist and this position. Compare Âèà, Êâã, ‰πù, Áà™.

Two possible interpretations: Starting from some bronze inscriptions, the dots have become elongated. Based on this form, Shuowen erroneously considers it to be an ideogrammic compound¬†(ÊúÉÊÑè):¬†ÂÖ´ (‚Äúto divide; to separate‚Äù)¬†+¬†‰∏® (‚Äúsmall object‚Äù). Compare with Â∞ë (OC *hmjew î, *hmjews), represented by four dots in its oracle bone script form.
Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã), a man with bent legs (jumping or collapsing). Compare with Â§ß, which derives from a man with straight legs, and in present form has slightly different strokes.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) - A man with his legs bending, and a side to the front. The picture is variously interpreted as either sitting or lying. When used as a radical, Â∞∏ is usually derived from a variation of ‰∫∫ or ‰∫ª, as in Â∞æ.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì three mountain peaks. In the Oracle Bone Script, they were represented by triangles rather than vertical strokes. Compare ‰∏ò (qi≈´), particularly earlier forms.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢).
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a bladed tool.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì silk rope for binding objects. Original form of Á¥Ä (OC *k…Ø î).
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a pestle. Also borrowed phonetically as a simplification of ‰πæ and Âππ.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢): A house that is built to depend on a cliff.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a man with one leg behind him, implying a stride.
Ideogrammic compound¬†(ÊúÉÊÑè):¬††Çá (‚Äúleft hand‚Äù)¬†+¬†Âèà (‚Äúright hand‚Äù), hence both hands.  Variant of Âªø.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì hand and fingers. The top stroke is the bent over middle finger, while the horizontal strokes are each two fingers. Compare Áà™, ÂØ∏, ‰πù. Note that unlike the other hand/claw characters, Êâã has consistently had five fingers: a mammalian/human hand, as opposed to the three digits often found in the others. Compare also Ê≠¢ (‚Äúfoot‚Äù), derived from a footprint, originally composed of 3 toes and a sole.
Shuowen: Half of Á´π + Âèà.
Phono-semantic compound¬†(ÂΩ¢ËÅ≤, OC *p ∞oÀê…°, *p ∞roÀê…°):¬†phonetic¬†Âçú (OC *poÀê…°)¬†+¬†semantic¬†Âèà (‚Äúhand‚Äù).

Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã): a man with a painted or tattooed chest ‚Äì original form of Á¥ã. In current form, tattoo has vanished, so simply an outline of a man (head, outstretched arms, legs, chest). Compare Â§ß, which has no chest.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) (Shuowen), indicating a ladle-shaped dou (see below) held by hand.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) - an axe.

Ideogrammic compound¬†(ÊúÉÊÑè):¬†‰∏Ä¬†+¬†ÂàÄ (‚Äúsword‚Äù) ‚Äì blade; tip of a blade. Original form of Ëäí (OC *maÀê≈ã, *ma≈ã, ‚Äúawn (of cereal); tip (of blade)‚Äù); later borrowed to mean ‚Äúside‚Äù. Other theories regarding the origin of this character also exist. It is unrelated to „´É (‚Äúfluttering flag‚Äù), from which characters like Êóó (OC *…°…Ø, ‚Äúflag‚Äù) and ÊóÖ (OC *…°¬∑ra î, ‚Äútroops‚Äù) are derived.

One of the three characters (ÁÑ°, Êó†, ‰∫°) that have historically been used to represent the word "no, not any". First attested in the Warring States period; used interchangeably with ÁÑ° until the Tang dynasty. Readopted by the PRC in 1956. The origin of this character is unknown. Probably an ancient variant form of either ÂÖÉ, Â§© or Â†Ø.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì the Sun. A dot or line was added in the centre to distinguish it from visually similar characters, e.g. Âõó (early form of ‰∏Å). Compare earlier forms of the character with the astronomical and astrological symbol for the Sun (‚òâ) and the Egyptian hieroglyph ìá≥.
Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã): a mouth (Âè£) with word or breath (‰∏Ä) coming out. Compare ‰ªä and Ë®Ä, where a small stroke is also used to represent words.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì pictographic representation of a crescent moon. Compare Â§ï.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a tree: branches on top, roots on the bottom (more visible in earlier forms).

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a footprint, originally meaning "foot". The derivative Ë∂æ (OC *kj…Ø î) refers to the original meaning. Compare Êâã (‚Äúhand‚Äù). Note that in oracle script, composed of 3 toes and a sole. Compare to Â§ä, Â§Ç, which have similar shape in oracle script, but pointing down (toe pointing right), and °ïí (as in right side of Ëàõ, roughly „É∞, toe pointing left), hence different evolution.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) - human remains.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) or Ideogrammic compound¬†(ÊúÉÊÑè):¬†Âá†¬†+¬†Âèà ‚Äì a hand holding a tool, hence activity.
In the oracle bone script, ÊØç (‚Äúmother‚Äù) was borrowed to represent this character. It was later specialized to distinguish it from ‚Äúmother‚Äù, replacing the two dots with one stroke.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì There are various interpretations: a man bending over to sow the field,[1] the root of a tree,[2] a man bowing over to the right, etc.

Ê∞î (OC *k ∞…Øds) is a pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) of clouds flowing through the sky. In the oracle bone script, it was represented by three horizontal strokes, expressing the "feeling" of the sky. However, in order to avoid confusion with the number ‰∏â (OC *suÀêm, *suÀêms), the current Ê∞î (OC *k ∞…Øds) was changed to draw a small stroke from top to bottom. The glyph of Ê∞£ (OC *k ∞…Øds, *q ∞…Øds) and ‰πû (OC *k ∞…Øds, *k ∞…Ød) comes from the same ancient form.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì pictographic representation of a fire.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢):¬†‰πÇ¬†+¬†‰πÇ ‚Äì 2 stacked ‚ÄòX‚Äô marks, indicating cuts or marks.

The character's shape was historically very similar to Áéã; a dot was introduced to differentiate the two. Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢): a picture of a cong (ÁêÆ), a sort of ritual jade totem. It is also interpreted as three pieces of jade strung together on a string.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢): a water bucket. Compare Ê°∂.

Unclear; probably a pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢). Guo (1954) suggests that it represents a thumb and is original form of Êãá (OC *m…Ø î) or, more probably, Êìò (OC *preÀê…°). Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì an altar. The original form is similar to unrelated character ‰∏Ö, and additional strokes are added to prevent confusion.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a person standing on the ground; compare Â§ß.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì two bamboo stalks, with leaves. Earlier forms resembled ‰∏™ + ‰∏™, current form resembles rather „Ç± + „Ç±.

Ideogrammic compound¬†(ÊúÉÊÑè):¬†‰∫∫ (‚Äúman‚Äù)¬†+¬†ÊØõ (‚Äúhair‚Äù)¬†+¬†Âåï (‚Äúcane‚Äù) ‚Äì a man with long hair (an old man), leaning on a cane. Compare top component to Â≠ù (OC *q ∞ruÀês). Cognate to ËÄÉ (OC *k ∞luÀê î); the most commonly cited example of ËΩâÊ≥® (‚Äúreciprocal meaning‚Äù).

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì ribs of an animal‚Äôs torso or simply a physical representation of a slice of meat. For more images, please refer to this link: http://humanum.arts.cuhk.edu.hk/Lexis/lexi-mf/search.php?word=ËÇâ

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì A vertical eye of a man looking downwards. As the individual character it is used as a metaphor meaning ‚Äúto surrender‚Äù, while the meaning relating to eyes appears when used as a radical, such as in Ëá® (‚Äúto look down at‚Äù).

Originally a pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) of a nose; in China (and East Asia) one points at one‚Äôs nose to indicate oneself, hence an ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã) of ‚Äúself‚Äù. The original meaning of ‚Äúnose‚Äù has been replaced by Èºª.

Note that the left foot has changed shape rather more than the right foot, which still resembles the form in earlier script.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢): a snake. The character originally represented a type of venomous snake, while the derivative Ëü≤ represented worms and insects (or insect-like things). Ëô´ was later borrowed for Ëü≤ (possibly via simplification), and the character Ëô∫ was created to represent the original meaning.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a street intersection. Originally symmetric, it has been simplified asymmetrically; the left half ÂΩ≥ is widely used as a radical, while the right half ‰∫ç finds occasional use, and the character can be broken up as ÂΩ≥¬†+¬†‰∫ç, though originally it was not a compound.

Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã): Ë®Ä was created by adding a mark to Ëàå to indicate movement of the tongue.[1] This indicates speech where Ëàå is a mouth (Âè£) with a tongue sticking out.  Shuowen erroneously analyzes the glyph as a phono-semantic compound¬†(ÂΩ¢ËÅ≤):¬†phonetic¬†‰áÇ¬†+¬†semantic¬†Âè£ (‚Äúmouth‚Äù).
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äî valley (Âè£) in between two mountains.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì some kind of container. Borrowed phonetically for the plant name. Displaced Old Chinese ËèΩ (sh≈´).

Ideogrammic compound¬†(ÊúÉÊÑè):¬†Â§≠ (‚Äúyoung, running man‚Äù)¬†+¬†Ê≠¢ (‚Äúfoot‚Äù) ‚Äì a running man. The top component (Â§≠) simplified to the unrelated Âúü. As with Âú≠, there are two separate vertical strokes, not a single one.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢): from a pictograph of a pregnant woman.

Ideogram (Êåá‰∫ã): It is derived from a pictogram of a carriage seen from above. In the oracle bone script, there were large wheels on both sides and a sun shade on the top. Later, when Chinese characters were written vertically, the wheels on both sides were simply drawn in strokes and the loading area was marked with a Áî∞ (OC *l'iÀê≈ã). Therefore, it is important to understand that the current character, Ëªä (OC *k ∞lja, *kla) is a vertical depiction of a carriage. Note that ÂÄù (OC *kaÀêns) (as in left part of Êúù (OC * îr'ew, *r'ew)) is not derived from Ëªä (OC *k ∞lja, *kla).
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì Picture of a tool - a carving knife or a chisel - used to mark slaves and criminals.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a kind of agricultural tool used for tilling the fields and removing weeds (Guo, 1931; Qiu, 1992), possibly made of a kind of large clam ËúÉ (OC *dj…Øns, *dj…Øn î, *djins) (Guo, 1931). Alternatively, it could be a pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) of a person holding onto a cliff ‚Äì original character of ÊåØ (OC *tj…Øn, *tj…Øns, ‚Äúto hold up‚Äù) (Shang, 1983).

Ideogrammic compound¬†(ÊúÉÊÑè):¬†Âõó¬†+¬†Âç™.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äî an ancient vase used in making and storing fermented millet alcoholic drink. See ÈÖí.

Originally referred to copper. Later, the meaning was extended to metal as a whole, and then to gold.  Phono-semantic compound¬†(ÂΩ¢ËÅ≤, OC *kr…Øm):¬†semantic¬†Áéã (‚Äúupside-down axe‚Äù)¬†+¬†semantic¬†ÂëÇ (‚Äútwo blocks of metal‚Äù)¬†+¬†phonetic¬†‰∫º. ‰∫º is the ancient form for ‰ªä (OC *kr…Øm).
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì originally long hair; compare ÂΩ°.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢): a gate. Compare Êà∂ (OC *…° ∑aÀê î, ‚Äú(one) door‚Äù), which is half of this character.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢):¬†Âèà¬†+¬†abbreviated¬†Â∞æ.
Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢): a short‚Äêtailed bird (e.g. a sparrow). Compare È≥•.

Pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) ‚Äì a stretched animal hide: the upper is head, the bottom is the tail and legs. Compare ÁöÆ, which also features a hide.

(Insects refer to any kind of animal, such as tigers (Â§ßËü≤)). In the oracle bone script, the character È≥≥ (OC *bums, ‚Äúmale fenghuang‚Äù) was phonetically borrowed to represent È¢® (OC *plum, *plums). The right part of the bronze inscription of the character consists of phonetic Âá° (OC *bom) at the top, and three parts depicting the fur on the tail of the male fenghuang at the bottom. Subsequent forms of È¢® are based on the right part of its bronze inscription, with two of the three threads of "fur" removed for simplification. The Ëô´ in the Chu script and Qin script of È¢® was likely a result of further simplification of the "fur". Shuowen misinterpreted the character È¢® by associating it with insects. (Li, 2012)

Phono-semantic compound¬†(ÂΩ¢ËÅ≤, OC *mr…ØÀê…°):¬†phonetic¬†‰æÜ (OC *m¬∑r…ØÀê…°)¬†+¬†semantic¬†Â§ä (‚Äúfoot; to walk slowly‚Äù). ‰æÜ was the original character for ‚Äúwheat‚Äù. Several possible interpretations:

According to Shuowen, it is both a phono-semantic compound¬†(ÂΩ¢ËÅ≤, OC *…° ∑aÀê≈ã)¬†and ideogrammic compound¬†(ÊúÉÊÑè):¬†phonetic¬†ÁÇó (‚Äúlight‚Äù)¬†+¬†semantic¬†Áî∞ (‚Äúfield‚Äù) ‚Äì the color of earth, with ÁÇó being the ancient form of ÂÖâ (OC *k ∑aÀê≈ã, *k ∑aÀê≈ãs, ‚Äúlight‚Äù). However, this interpretation is likely erroneous as Âªø at the top was formed as a result of corruption of Âè£ in the bronze inscription.  Chi (2010) proposes that ÈªÉ was originally a pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) and the original character of Â∞™ (OC *q ∑aÀê≈ã, ‚Äúa disabled person with a protruding chest or abdomen‚Äù). It has been phonetically borrowed for "yellow" since the era of the oracle bone script. He (1998) noted the possible ritual of burning disabled people with a protruding chest or abdomen to pray for rain as mentioned in Zuozhuan. The Âè£ in the upper part of the bronze inscription of ÈªÉ might be depicting the disabled person's face facing upwards. Li (2012), on the other hand, proposes that ÈªÉ was originally a pictogram (Ë±°ÂΩ¢) and the original character of Áíú (OC *…° ∑aÀê≈ã, ‚Äúsemicircular jade‚Äù) as the Âè£ in the oracle bone script resembles a ring of jade, so the character would carry the meaning of "a man wearing a ring of jade on his chest". The meaning "yellow" is the result of rebus.
